text: Amazing!
Thanks for joining us this year!

1) The subject of our most listened-to show of 2017: Irish immigration 
2) Expect more literary topics next year. We loved our shows on the Algonquin Round Table and Edgar Allan Poe.
Catch up on our entire menu of 2017 shows here:http://www.boweryboyshistory.com/2017/12/bowery-boys-podcast-year-review-2017.html …
Good luck in future projects @BenJMorse!
Thanks Jennie happy new year to you! And thanks for listening and supporting us on Patreon.

Have you listened to our chat with Roz Chast yet? We talk about tourists, beloved diners, curious pests, New York in the late 1970s and her father's sage advice --http://www.boweryboyshistory.com/2017/12/going-town-new-yorkers-roz-chast-conversation-bowery-boys.html …

The Bowery Boys podcast: Year in Review 2017. We visited the histories of Soho, Astoria and Seneca Village. We explored tales of the Algonquin Round Table, the Wall Street Crash of 1929 and the birth of photography. And we met Poe, Barnum and Captain Kidd. http://bit.ly/2zLDyAu pic.twitter.com/wZTuIj2g8Z

Ninety years ago today, the musical Show Boat, by Jerome Kern and a young Oscar Hammerstein II, made its debut at the Ziegfeld Theatre. The show would permanently change the Broadway musical form. More in our Rodgers/Hammerstein podcast: http://bit.ly/2BdgtZS pic.twitter.com/TzkhbldQC0

Radio City Music Hall opened 85 years ago this evening -- with an extravagant variety of acts who performed into the early morning. That night, a version of the Rockettes (called the Roxyettes) also performed. They've been there ever since: http://bit.ly/2CcWon6 pic.twitter.com/V65ImCdZY7

The Flushing Remonstrance, petition of grievances against Peter Stuyvesant's anti-Quaker policies, was sent by residents of Vlissengen (today Flushing, Queens) 360 yrs ago today. The document is precursor to U.S. Constitution's freedom of religion clause. http://bit.ly/2Cf6M0d pic.twitter.com/gVX9KDzJ6L
Thanks Jason!

Carl Fisher, an Indiana businessman who sold automobile headlights, not only pushed for the construction of the first public highway in 1912. He also helped build @IMS, home of the Indy 500. More in the new episode of @TheFirstPodcast: http://bit.ly/2Bw99fy pic.twitter.com/lvlTOnHyK4
What a great selection!
